JOONEGAP

JOONEGAP is a small collection of classes to combine the power of JOONE with that of JGAP, providing an easy way for developers to start breeding genetically evolved neural networks to solve a broad class of problems.

JOONEGAP has been deliberately kept small, with an easy learning curve. Its handful of classes form a basic framework that takes care of:

  • Converting JGAP chromosomes to and from JOONE neural networks
  • Serializing and deserializing chromosomes to disk
  • Evolving a population of chromosomes through competition
To use JOONEGAP, you will need both the JOONE engine and JGAP libraries, as well as Log4J for logging.

The handful of classes come with several examples to get you up and running, the first (and easiest) being to solve the XOR problem:

XOR

To solve the XOR problem, only one class needs to be extended from the JOONEGAP framework (XORNeuralNetManager, extends NeuralNetManager), and only one extra class needs to be written (XORTest) to actually co-ordinate the test.

XORNeuralNetManager

XORNeuralNetManager defines a simple '2 in, 4 hidden, 2 out' neural network, with the first two inputs being the inputs from a XOR truth table, and the last two representing '0' and '1'.

For such a simple problem as XOR, it is tempting to simply have one output node and assign discrete values to it based on whether it is, say, greater than or less than 0.5. However, for a broader set of problems (say, facial recognition), discrete values are more commonplace (say, each output node representing a person's name), so for the sake of example we adopt that latter approach here.

In addition to building an uninitialised '2,4,2' JOONE network, XORNeuralNetManager also defines a method to 'interpret' each of the two output nodes as either representing '0' or '1'. This is useful for the XORTest class.

Finally, XORNeuralNetManager employs an optional feature of the JOONEGAP framework: to initially train new neural networks using standard back-prop - in many cases, this can speed up how long it takes to find a genetically-evolved solution.

Of course, back-prop is pefectly capable of solving a broad set of problems on its own, so for this example we don't want the training to be too perfect! Instead, we train the network to output the XOR truth table but with the last value deliberately incorrect. It is this last value we shall try to train using our genetic algorithms.

XORTest

XORTest supplies a 'main' method for clients to run, which will cycle and evolve the networks until one is found that successfully responds to the XOR input.

It starts by setting up the Log4J logger and XORNeuralNetManager. Then it cycles forever, using NeuralNetManager's 'hold' and 'release' methods to grab hold of new neural networks, and tries each one against a standard set of XOR tests (note that it doesn't keep score itself, it lets the JOONEGAP framework do that). The first network that passes all the tests breaks out the loop and completes the 'main' method.

The beauty of the JOONEGAP framework is that simply calling 'NeuralNetManager.hold' is enough to...

  • Create a new, uninitialised JOONE neural network
  • Train it using back-prop (if desired)
  • Convert it to a JGAP chromosome
  • Store that chromosome to disk
  • Track how many games each chromosome has played
  • Evolve all the chromosomes (the genotype) when necessary
...all 'behind the scenes'!

NIM

(with thanks to Mitchell Timin)

To solve the NIM problem, only one class needs to be extended from the JOONEGAP framework (NIMNeuralNetManager, extends NeuralNetManager), and only one extra class needs to be written (NIMTest) to actually co-ordinate the test.

NIM is a very simple game, trivial for a game theorist, but it serves well as a test vehicle for simulated evolution. This version of NIM is as follows: Two players begin the game with 15 "beans". They take turns removing beans. On each turn a player may remove 1, 2 or 3 beans. He must remove at least one, and may not take more than 3. The player removing the last bean loses.

A player of NIM must be able to decide what to do when presented with 15, or 14, or 13, etc. beans down to two beans. This decision could be in the form of a simple table, and in fact the following table shows how to play the most perfect game possible:

Remainder:15141312111098765432
Take away:21x321x321x321

A player following this strategy will always win if he has the first move. If the opponent has the first move, and if the opponent deviates from this table, then the player will also win. If both follow the table exactly the the player who goes first always wins. The x means that it doesn't matter; you will lose anyway.

NIMNeuralNetManager

NIMNeuralNetManager defines a '1 in, 30 hidden, 3 out' neural network, with the input being the number of beans left, and the output nodes how many beans to play (the first means 'play 3 beans', the second 'play 2 beans', and the third 'play 1 bean').

In addition to building the uninitialised '1,30,3' JOONE network, NIMNeuralNetManager also defines the method to 'interpret' each of the output nodes. This is useful for the NIMTest class.

NIMTest

NIMTest supplies a 'main' method for clients to run, which will cycle and evolve the networks until one is found that plays a perfect game of NIM.

It starts by setting up the Log4J logger and NIMNeuralNetManager. Then it cycles forever, using NeuralNetManager's 'hold' and 'release' methods to grab hold of new neural networks, and plays each one against another.

In addition, NIMTest applies a general test to see if the 'perfect' NIM player has been evolved yet. The first network that reaches this stage breaks out the loop and completes the 'main' method.

Once each network has played 20 games (specified in NIMNeuralNetManager), the entire population of chromosomes (the Genotype) is evolved by JGAP. The beauty of the JOONEGAP framework is that this happens transparently to NIMTest!
